title: Disclosure of 152 cookie names via crafted input

profile.name: Automattic
profile.about: WordPress.com, VaultPress, Akismet, Gravatar, WooCommerce, Polldaddy, Tumblr and more!

vulnerability_information:
If someone sends a cookie called '0', automattic.com responds with a list of all 152 cookies supported by the application:

curl -v -H 'Cookie: 0=1' https://automattic.com/?cb=123 | fgrep Cookie


## Impact

This is a low impact issue - it doesn't pose a direct threat by itself, but it discloses information which may be useful an attacker.
vulnerability_information_html:
If someone sends a cookie called '0', automattic.com responds with a list of all 152 cookies supported by the application:

curl -v -H 'Cookie: 0=1' https://automattic.com/?cb=123 | fgrep Cookie

Impact

activities.message: Hi. Thanks for the report. We'll take a look.
activities.markdown_message: Hi. Thanks for the report. We'll take a look.

activities.message: Hi. This should be now resolved.

Thanks, looks fixed from here. 

Just out of interest, could you briefly explain how it is that sending a cookie called 0 caused this behaviour? I'm struggling to imagine what the code looks like, and curious to know if this technique might work elsewhere.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks, looks fixed from here.

Just out of interest, could you briefly explain how it is that sending a cookie called 0 caused this behaviour? I'm struggling to imagine what the code looks like, and curious to know if this technique might work elsewhere.

The code to remove cookies was relying on a loose comparison, something like 

if ( ! in_array( $id, $some_cookie_based_set ) ) {
   setcookie( ... );
}
